installSubTitle.message: Crossfoam turns filter bubbles into lenses on the public.

installIntro.message:
Crossfoam is a browser extension to visualise and utilise your filter bubbles on Twitter.

Other social networks will follow soon.

installSpecialHeadline.message: We live our lives in bubbles.

installParagraph1.message: Our friends, our sources, and our conversations are not randomly selected. Instead we are much more likely to hear information which tilts towards our own opinions, likes and interests.

installParagraph2.message: While there are bubbles everywhere, they take on a special character in our electronic lives. Self-selection, curation by algorithms, and economic incentives often shape online communities into echo chambers, where everyone agrees, and everyone repeats the same opinions.

installParagraph3.message: Other communities with other backgrounds, other ideas and other opinions exist, but we are actively cut off from them. The result is repetition and sameness on the one hand and misunderstanding on the other.

installParagraph4.message: Crossfoam analyses and visualises your filter bubbles on social media, so you can discover the extent to which your online community is an echo chamber or a place of diverse opinions. Fine-grained analysis allows you to explore your social network, diversify it, or - if you prefer - dig deeper into your bubble. Crossfoam thus becomes a tool for electronic self-determination.

servicesTwitterAuthorizeNote.message:
If you want to collect data from Twitter, you need to authorize yourself. Authorization is free. ULTRAPOP will not know how you use the widget, data is coming directly from Twitter to you.

When you click on the button below a new window or tab will open. Please follow the instructions. In the end you will receive a code. Return to this page and enter the code below.

servicesTwitterAuthorized.message: Twitter is enabled and ready to go.

visListLegend.message: Connections within the bubble;Many;Few;Highlight bubble on service;or hide

visClusterIntro.message: Explore the clusters, go down to the individual friends and their networks.

visOverviewIntro.message:
A user's friends and their friends have the strongest impact on what they see in their timeline.
But who are those people?

visNetworkIntro.message: Strongly interconnected clusters can be an indicator for a very homogenous circle of friends. Explore by switching the links to other clusters on and off.

nameNotAvailable.message: Sorry, we do not have the real username of this person.

updateVersion.message: Crossfoam was updated from $V1$ to $V2$.

updateMessage.message: Improved performance.;Removing unused objects from local storage to free disk space.;A new visualisation for cluster exploration.

selectionInProgress.message: Data collection is still in progress.

selectionIntro.message: Select one of the accounts below to explore the account's network and edit the bubble-labels and colors, $IMG1$ export the network data or $IMG2$ delete all data connected to that account.

noDataYet.message:
Sorry, but there is no information collected, yet.
Please collect some data first.
Check out the help page for more information.

githubPromote.message: If you want to know more about the changes, take a look at our Repository on GitHub. The whole Crossfoam web extension is open source:

extensionDescription.message: Crossfoam is a tool for analyzing social networks.

settingsClusterDescription.message: While browsing the web, the web-extension can identify people that are within one of the clusters labeled in one of your data collections. When you go into each data collection (list view) you can turn the highlighting for specific clusters on (and off). The default is, that all clusters are off.

settingsClusterNote.message: Browser-extensions are individual processes running in the background of your browser. Thereby, they consume ressources. We generally recommend you turn this feature or even the extension on, only if you need it.

invalidLinkMessage.message: The link you clicked is not a valid user-url this extension supports. Please right-click on a user-link. A full tutorial can be found on our website: LINK.

duplicateLinkMessage.message: It looks like an analysis for username $1 was already requested. Do you wish to request another analysis?

authRequiredMessage.message: Sorry, you need to first authorise the service $1 on the options page.

exportGdfDesc.message: Database table with definitions, used by GUESS (all attributes)

exportDotDesc.message: DOT file used by GraphViz (all attributes)

exportTlpDesc.message: TLP format used by Tulip (only topology, no weights)

exportNetdrawDesc.message: VNA format used by Netdraw (all attributes)

exportCsvDesc.message: comma-separated values, one file each for nodes & edges (all attributes)

exportJson2Desc.message: JSON files, one file each for nodes & edges (all attributes)

helpCluster_1.message: In this view, you can further explore the clusters. By clicking on one of the clusters, you can see all the accounts that are part of this cluster.

helpCluster_2.message: From here, you can go further and get the sub-network of an individual user.

helpCluster_3.message: Important note: the individual user's networks are only the connections within in the current network. Each user will likely have more connections to people not present in this dataset.

helpCluster_4.message: Using the button in the upper right: 'show/hide proxies' you can also see connections only established through a proxy. If you want to know more about proxies, click here.

helpList_1.message: This is the List Vis, here you can quickly find people in the network and modify the cluster names and colors.

helpList_2.message: Use the search bar in the upper left to find someone.

helpList_3.message: If you move your mouse over a user, a link will appear allowing you to jump to this user's friends within the current network or visit the user's social media profile.

helpList_4.message: Click the small pen icon next to a cluster's name to rename a cluster or change it's color.

helpList_5.message: By clicking the small eye next to the pen, you can toggle if this network should be highlighted next to respective accounts when browsing social media. Note: You can also disable this feature completely in the settings.

helpOverview_1.message: This is the overview visualiation. Here we show you all the friends of the selected user. But why is this of interest?

helpOverview_2.message: The content that is shown to you on a social media platform, is not only influenced by the content you previously interacted with, but also strongly through the people you mark as friends.

helpOverview_3.message: Let's take twitter as an example. The content in your Twitter timeline is mostly influenced by the people who are your friends. When your freinds tweet, retweet or like something, it is more likely to show up in your timeline.

helpOverview_4.message: If more of your friends interact with a tweet, the more likely it is to be shown prominently in your timeline.

helpOverview_5.message: In the middle of the visualisation you see the user's direct friends. The bigger the circle is, the more connected this person is to the rest of the other friends and, thereby, the more likely it is that their content shows up in the user's timeline.

helpOverview_6.message: The second area are the user's friends' friends who are not direct friends. The bigger their circle is, the more of the user's friends they know and, thereby the more likely it is that the user themselves will see content from them.

helpOverview_7.message: The most outer area shows the user's friends' friends who only know one of the user's friends.

helpOverview_8.message: While this might seam obvious, it is important to remember, that the people we mark as friends, have a strong influence on what we see on our social media outlets and, thereby, influence our view on the world.

helpNetwork_1.message: This is the network visualiation. Here we show you all the friends of the selected user and their connections.

helpNetwork_2.message: In most cases, those connections will turn into a mess. This is also know as the 'hairball' effect.

helpNetwork_3.message: If you want to explore the connections more in depth, please use the cluster view.

helpNetwork_4.message: In this network view you can easily identify outliers, for example people who are not connected to anyone else.

helpNetwork_5.message: You can identify how strong clusters are connected to one another and which people are particular central within or between clusters.

helpNetwork_6.message: If it looks like everyone is connected to everyone else, then the overall network is likely to be very homogenous, which can likely result in similar opinions in this network.

helpNetwork_7.message: While we assign a cluster to each user, this is not absoulte. Use the toggle in the upper right to see, if users are also connected to other clusters.
